questions.question: According to Le Chatelier's Principle, if more reactant is added to a system at equilibrium, the system will shift to the:
options: Right (products) to consume the added reactant
Left (reactants) to produce more reactant
Right (products) because the equilibrium constant K has increased
Left (reactants) because the reaction quotient Q has increased
questions.explanation: Adding a reactant makes $Q < K$. The system counteracts this by shifting forward to consume the excess and restore the equilibrium ratio.

questions.question: If a product is continuously removed from a reaction vessel as it forms, the reaction will:
options: Continue to shift toward the products (right)
Shift toward the reactants (left) to restore the product
Reach equilibrium much faster
Stop completely because of the missing material
questions.explanation: Removing a product keeps $Q$ lower than $K$, forcing the reaction to stay in the 'forward' mode. This is a common industrial technique to increase yield.

questions.question: In the equilibrium $Fe^{3+}(aq) + SCN^{-}(aq) \rightleftharpoons FeSCN^{2+}(aq)$, adding extra $SCN^{-}$ ions will cause the solution to:
options: Become darker (more product formed)
Become lighter (more reactant formed)
Remain the same color as K is constant
Turn colorless as the reaction stops
questions.explanation: Increasing the concentration of a reactant ($SCN^{-}$) shifts the equilibrium to the right, increasing the concentration of the deep-red complex $FeSCN^{2+}$.

questions.question: What happens to the value of the equilibrium constant $K$ when concentrations are changed at constant temperature?
options: The value of K remains unchanged
K increases if more reactant is added
K decreases if more product is added
K increases only if a catalyst is present
questions.explanation: Only temperature can change the value of $K$. Concentration changes shift the *position* of equilibrium, but the system eventually settles at the same ratio.

questions.question: If a reactant is removed from an equilibrium system, the system will shift:
options: Toward the reactants (left) to replace what was lost
Toward the products (right) to maintain the forward rate
Toward the products (right) because Q is now zero
Nowhere, as only adding substances causes a shift
questions.explanation: Le Chatelier's Principle states the system tries to 'undo' the change. Removing a reactant causes a shift to the side where that reactant is produced.

questions.question: Consider the reaction: $N_{2}(g) + 3H_{2}(g) \rightleftharpoons 2NH_{3}(g)$. If $NH_{3}$ is added to the container, the concentration of $H_{2}$ will:
options: Increase
Decrease
Remain the same
Drop to zero
questions.explanation: Adding product ($NH_{3}$) causes a shift to the left (reactants). This results in the formation of more $N_{2}$ and $H_{2}$.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the effect of adding a pure solid to an equilibrium involving gases?
options: No shift occurs because solids are not included in the equilibrium expression
The reaction shifts away from the solid to reduce the mass
The reaction shifts toward the solid to help it dissolve
The value of K increases significantly
questions.explanation: Since the 'concentration' of a pure solid is constant, adding more of it does not change the ratio of the $Q$ expression and thus does not cause a shift.

questions.question: If a system is at equilibrium and we double the concentrations of ALL species simultaneously, the system will shift:
options: Toward the side with fewer moles of particles
Toward the side with more moles of particles
Not at all, since the ratio remains the same
Only if the reaction is exothermic
questions.explanation: Doubling all concentrations increases the numerator and denominator by different factors if the stoichiometric coefficients are different (e.g., $2^{2} / 2^{1} = 2$), causing a shift.

questions.question: In the reaction $A(g) \rightleftharpoons B(g)$, if we add $A$ and $B$ such that the ratio $[B]/[A]$ remains equal to $K$, what happens?
options: No shift occurs
The reaction shifts to the right
The reaction shifts to the left
The reaction stops
questions.explanation: If the ratio of product to reactant still equals $K$ ($Q=K$), the system is still at equilibrium and no net shift is required.

questions.question: In industrial processes, the 'yield' of a product is maximized by:
options: Removing the product as it is formed
Adding more product to the reaction vessel
Decreasing the concentration of all reactants
Using a very small reaction vessel
questions.explanation: By removing product, you ensure $Q < K$ at all times, driving the reaction forward until the reactants are nearly exhausted.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand how systems react to concentration stress.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You have a solid grasp of Le Chatelier's Principle.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: the system always tries to undo the change you make.
scoreMessages.0: Review the concept of shifts in equilibrium due to concentration changes.
